marketNews.title: Indonesia Economy +4.87% YoY in 1Q25, Weakest since 3Q21
marketNews.content:
Indonesia's Central Statistics Agency (BPS) reported that the country's economy grew only 4.87 percent year-on-year (YoY) in the first quarter of 2025, compared with 5.11 percent YoY in 1Q24 and 5.02 percent YoY in 4Q24. This fell short of the consensus forecast of 4.91 percent YoY and marked the weakest quarterly growth since the third quarter of 2021. The result is also below the government’s 2025 target of 5.2 percent YoY, although it remains within Bank Indonesia’s target range of roughly 4.7-5.5 percent YoY.

On a quarter-on-quarter basis, GDP contracted 0.98 percent in 1Q25 (vs. a 0.83 percent contraction in 1Q24), again weaker than the consensus expectation of a 0.89 percent decline.

The slowdown in annual growth was driven by weaker household consumption, which rose only 4.89 percent YoY versus 4.91 percent YoY in 1Q24, and a drop in government consumption of 1.42 percent YoY versus a 19.9 percent increase in 1Q24. The decline occurred amid the Lebaran season, government incentive programmes, and tighter fiscal spending.

BPS head Amalia Adininggar Widyasanti attributed the weakening of household and government consumption to a high-base effect from the 2024 general election. She also noted that the impact of the 2025 state-budget efficiency measures ordered by President Prabowo Subianto in January 2025 on government consumption will become more visible in 2Q25.

In addition to consumption, gross fixed capital formation (GFCF) also weakened, growing only 2.12 percent YoY versus 3.78 percent YoY in 1Q24, reflecting a “wait-and-see” attitude among investors toward global economic developments.

Annual GDP growth in 1Q25 was supported mainly by net exports, which contributed 0.83 percentage points (vs. 0.06 pp in 1Q24), and other variables contributing 0.86 pp (vs. 0.16 pp in 1Q24).

By sector, agriculture posted the largest contribution, expanding 10.52 percent YoY (vs. a 3.54 percent contraction in 1Q24) and adding 1.11 percentage points to GDP growth (vs. 0.07 pp in 4Q24 and –0.41 pp in 1Q24), driven by a bumper harvest of rice and corn.

Regionally, growth was weakest in Maluku and Papua (+1.69 percent YoY), Bali and Nusa Tenggara (+3.12 percent YoY), Kalimantan (+4.32 percent YoY) and Sumatra (+4.85 percent YoY). Sulawesi and Java outperformed the national average, recording 6.4 percent YoY and 4.99 percent YoY respectively.

In a separate statement, National Development Planning Minister Rachmat Pambudy said on Monday (May 5) that the government targets GDP growth of about 5.8-6.3 percent YoY for 2026.

Key Takeaway

Although Indonesia’s economy could accelerate in the second half of 2025 as government spending rises and interest rates are cut, the ongoing US-China trade dispute creates uncertainty for future growth. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani warned that a 32 percent US tariff could shave 0.3-0.5 percentage points off Indonesia’s growth. Previously, the World Bank and IMF had lowered their 2025 growth outlooks from 5.1 percent YoY to 4.7 percent YoY.

marketNews.title: Other Hot Topics to Know
marketNews.content:
1. Bloomberg consensus expects Bank Indonesia to cut rates two more times to 5.25% by the end of 2025, with 25 bps cuts at the end of 2Q25 and another 25 bps at 3Q25. The consensus also expects consumer price index inflation to be 1.8% YoY in 2Q25 and 2% YoY in 2025, lower than previous expectations of 1.9% YoY and 2.1% YoY.

2. BPS reported that the open unemployment rate fell by 0.06 percentage points to 4.76% in February 2025, driven by labor-force participation rising 0.80 pp, the labor force growing by 3.67 million to 153.05 million, and employed persons increasing by 3.59 million to 145.77 million.

3. BPS reported average wages rose 1.78% YoY in February 2025 from 3.04 million rupiah to 3.09 million rupiah.

4. Eight OPEC+ member countries on Saturday (May 3) agreed to increase oil production by 411,000 barrels per day starting June 2025. The total increase for April-June 2025 will be 960,000 bpd, equivalent to 44% of the previous cut of 2.2 million bpd. In response, WTI futures for June 2025 fell 3.6% to $56.19 per barrel on Monday morning.

5. Berkshire Hathaway CEO Warren Buffett announced he will step down at the end of 2025, ending a 60-year tenure. He will be succeeded by Vice Chairman Greg Abel.

6. Bloomberg reported that Garuda Indonesia (GIAA) has grounded at least 15 aircraft due to payment difficulties for maintenance, mainly from its Citilink unit. Suppliers are demanding advance payments for parts and labor. GIAA currently operates 66 aircraft and has 14 stored.

7. Shareholder of DEWA, PT Madhani Talatah Nusantara, sold about 493 million DEWA shares at 75 rupiah each on 29 April 2025, total value ~37 billion rupiah. After the transaction, its ownership fell from 24.81% to 23.59%.

8. Controlling shareholder and Chairman of Tripar Multivision Plus (RAAM), Ram Jethmal Punjabi, bought about 5.2 million RAAM shares at an average price of 301 rupiah each on 24 and 28 April 2025, total value ~1.6 billion rupiah. Ownership increased from 70.946% to 71.022%.

9. Controlling shareholder and President Director of Sarana Mitra Luas (SMIL), Hadi Suhermin, bought 20 million SMIL shares at 256 rupiah each on 2 May 2025, total value ~5.1 billion rupiah. Ownership rose from 50.32% to 50.55%.

10. Shareholders of Acset Indonusa (ACST) approved a private placement of up to 5 billion new shares at an execution price of 100 rupiah each, potentially diluting existing shareholders by up to 28%. The proceeds will be used to strengthen the capital structure and improve the company's financial condition, which currently shows negative equity. The placement will be taken up by the controlling shareholder, PT Karya Supra Perkasa.

tickerNews.title: TPIA Announces Plan for IPO Raising up to Rp2.4 Trillion
tickerNews.content: TPIA reported that its subsidiary Chandra Daya Investasi, a unit of Chandra Asri Pacific, plans to conduct an IPO of approximately 12.5 billion shares priced between 170 and 190 rupiah per share. The maximum proceeds from this corporate action could reach about 2.4 trillion rupiah. The report is based on the preliminary prospectus of PT Chandra Daya Investasi. In February 2025, TPIA indicated that the subsidiary was considering an IPO on the Indonesia Stock Exchange.

tickerNews.title: PTBA Studies $3.1 Billion Investment in Coal-to-Gas Project with PGAS
tickerNews.content: Bukit Asam (PTBA) said it is studying a plan to invest US$3.1 billion in a coal-to-synthetic natural gas project together with state-owned gas company PGAS. The project would convert 8.4 million tonnes of PTBA coal (calorific value 3,700 kcal/kg) into 240 billion standard cubic feet of gas. The plant will be built by a joint venture of PTBA, PGAS and a third-party technology provider, which was not disclosed.

tickerNews.title: SIDO Declares Final Dividend for FY2024 of 21 Rupiah per Share
tickerNews.content: Sido Muncul announced a final dividend for the 2024 fiscal year of 630 billion rupiah, equivalent to 21 rupiah per share, representing a final dividend yield of 3.9%. The dividend is payable on Monday (May 5) with a cum-date on the regular market and a record date on May 14, 2025, and payment on May 26, 2025. Previously, SIDO paid an interim dividend of 540 billion rupiah (18 rupiah per share) in November 2024, bringing total dividends for FY2024 to roughly 1.2 trillion rupiah, a 100% payout ratio.

tickerNews.title: AMRT Reports Q1 Net Profit of 975 Billion Rupiah (+10% YoY, +30% QoQ)
tickerNews.content: Alfamart (AMRT) posted a net profit of 975 billion rupiah for 1Q25, up 10% YoY and 30% QoQ, matching the consensus estimate of 25% of the 2025F consensus. Revenue grew to 32.7 trillion rupiah (+12% YoY, +9% QoQ), also in line with the consensus. Operating margin remained stable at 3.8% (vs. 3.9% in 1Q24 and 3.2% in 4Q24). Operating profit rose to 1.3 trillion rupiah (+10% YoY, +30% QoQ), exceeding the consensus at 29% of the 2025F estimate.

tickerNews.title: MAPI Reports Same-Store Sales Growth of +0.1% YoY in Q1
tickerNews.content: Mitra Adiperkasa (MAPI) recorded same-store sales growth (SSSG) of +0.1% YoY in 1Q25, compared with –1.1% YoY in 1Q24 and 0% in 4Q24. The result was supported by the 'active' segment under Map Aktif Adiperkasa (MAPA), which posted SSSG of +2.9% YoY, and the 'retail/specialty stores' segment, also at +0.1% YoY. Conversely, the 'café & restaurant' segment under Map Boga Adiperkasa (MAPB) saw SSSG decline by –9.4% YoY in 1Q25 (vs. –27.6% YoY in 1Q24 and –15% YoY in 4Q24).

tickerNews.title: CNMA Announces Record April Attendance of Over 14 Million Viewers
tickerNews.content: Cinema XXI (CNMA) reported that its cinema network attracted more than 14 million moviegoers in April 2025, setting an all-time high for the company. The previous monthly record was 11.7 million viewers in June 2019. The achievement was credited to a strong lineup of both local and international films.

tickerNews.title: TUGU Declares FY2024 Dividend of ~280 Billion Rupiah (78.8 Rupiah per Share)
tickerNews.content: Asuransi Tugu Pratama (TUGU) will distribute a dividend for the 2024 fiscal year of approximately 280 billion rupiah, or about 78.8 rupiah per share, representing a dividend payout ratio of roughly 40% and a dividend yield of 7.6%. The cum-date is on the regular market, with a record date on May 8, 2025, and payment on May 28, 2025.

tickerNews.title: PWON Plans 2025 Capex of 2.48 Trillion Rupiah, 59% for Construction
tickerNews.content: Pakuwon Jati (PWON) announced a 2025 capital expenditure budget of 2.48 trillion rupiah, down from 2.71 trillion rupiah in 2024. About 59% of the budget will be allocated to construction projects, with the remainder for expansion. The company will expand existing superblocks such as Kota Kasablanka, Gandaria City, Pakuwon Mall Bekasi, and Pakuwon City Mall Surabaya, adding retail, residential, hotel, and office space. PWON also plans to open three new hotels in 2025.

tickerNews.title: ULTJ Announces FY2024 Dividend of ~468 Billion Rupiah (45 Rupiah per Share)
tickerNews.content: Ultrajaya Milk Industry & Trading Company (ULTJ) will pay a dividend for the 2024 fiscal year of approximately 468 billion rupiah, or 45 rupiah per share, corresponding to a dividend payout ratio of about 41% and a dividend yield of 3.3%. The cum-date is on the regular market, with a record date on May 14, 2025, and payment on June 5, 2025.

tickerNews.title: GIAA Grounds at Least 15 Aircraft Due to Maintenance Payment Issues
tickerNews.content: Garuda Indonesia (GIAA) has grounded at least 15 aircraft because of difficulties in paying for maintenance, mainly affecting its Citilink unit. Some suppliers are demanding advance payments for parts and labor due to concerns over the airline’s financial situation. GIAA currently operates 66 aircraft, with 14 aircraft stored.

tickerNews.title: DEWA Shareholder Sells Approximately 493 Million Shares
tickerNews.content: A shareholder of Darma Henwa (DEWA), PT Madhani Talatah Nusantara, sold about 493 million DEWA shares at a price of 75 rupiah per share on 29 April 2025, generating roughly 37 billion rupiah. After the transaction, its ownership fell from 24.81% to 23.59%.

tickerNews.title: RAAM Chairman Purchases ~5.2 Million Shares at 301 Rupiah
tickerNews.content: Ram Jethmal Punjabi, controlling shareholder and Chairman of Tripar Multivision Plus (RAAM), bought approximately 5.2 million RAAM shares at an average price of 301 rupiah per share on 24 and 28 April 2025, for a total transaction value of about 1.6 billion rupiah. His ownership increased from 70.946% to 71.022%.

tickerNews.title: SMIL Controlling Owner Buys 20 Million Shares at 256 Rupiah
tickerNews.content: Hadi Suhermin, controlling shareholder and President Director of Sarana Mitra Luas (SMIL), purchased 20 million SMIL shares at 256 rupiah each on 2 May 2025, amounting to roughly 5.1 billion rupiah. His direct ownership rose from 50.32% to 50.55%.

tickerNews.title: ACST Approves Private Placement of Up to 5 Billion New Shares
tickerNews.content: Acset Indonusa (ACST) shareholders approved a private placement of up to 5 billion additional shares at an execution price of 100 rupiah per share, which could dilute existing shareholders by up to 28%. The funds will be used to strengthen the capital structure and improve the company's financial condition, which currently shows negative equity. The placement will be taken up by the controlling shareholder, PT Karya Supra Perkasa.
